context: Once the presence of bacteria was documented, the density of H pylori was graded in each specimen by a semiquantitative scale, ranged from 0 to 5. 16 H pylori culture The 3 gastric biopsies taken for culture during endoscopy were immediately transferred into brain heart infusion (BHI; Difco Laboratory, Detroit, Mich.) in ice and inoculated onto CDC anaerobic blood agar (BBL; Microbiology Systems, Cockeysville, Md.). The agar was incubated at 35° C for 2 days in a microaerophilic gas mixture composed of 5% O2, 10% CO2, and 85% N2 (Difco Laboratory). H pylori was identified on the basis of rapid urea hydrolysis, catalase, oxidase production, and API Campy kit (bioMerieux, Marcy-L'Etolle, France). 17 13C urea breath test Within 3 days before endoscopy, each patient completed a modified UBT protocol 18 that included ingestion of urea premixed with a 100 mL fatty test meal to prolong the gastric emptying after an overnight fast and use of mouthwash before the test. The expired UBT gas samples were collected in duplicate at baseline (pretest) and 15 minutes after ingestion of 100 mg 13C-labeled urea (INER-Hp13C-tester; Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taipei, Taiwan). These gas samples were collected separately for analysis of the 13CO2/12CO2 ratio (δ13CO2 per mil) by a continuous flow isotope ratio mass spectrometer (Atomatic Breath Carbon Analyzer; Europa Scientific, Crewe, U.K.) and labeled as A (baseline sample) and B (15-minute sampling), respectively. The choice of 15 minutes after ingestion for sampling was based on our previous study, which confirmed that 15-minute gas sampling could achieve effective qualitative and quantitative UBT results.
